questions.question: What is classification of living organisms?
questions.answer: Classification is the systematic arrangement of living organisms into groups based on similarities and differences. It helps in easy study and identification of organisms.

questions.question: Why is classification necessary?
questions.answer: Classification helps to organize large numbers of organisms. It makes study easier and shows relationships among organisms.

questions.question: What is binomial nomenclature?
questions.answer: Binomial nomenclature is a system of naming organisms using two words: genus and species. It was introduced by Carl Linnaeus.

questions.question: What are prokaryotic organisms?
questions.answer: Prokaryotic organisms do not have a true nucleus or membrane-bound organelles. Bacteria are examples of prokaryotes.

questions.question: What are eukaryotic organisms?
questions.answer: Eukaryotic organisms have a true nucleus and membrane-bound organelles. Plants, animals, fungi and protists are eukaryotes.

questions.question: What are microorganisms?
questions.answer: Microorganisms are very small living organisms that cannot be seen with naked eyes. They are seen using a microscope.

questions.question: Where are microorganisms found?
questions.answer: Microorganisms are found everywhere such as in water, air, soil, and inside living organisms. Some also live in extreme conditions.

questions.question: What are bacteria?
questions.answer: Bacteria are single-celled prokaryotic organisms. They can be beneficial or harmful to humans.

questions.question: How do bacteria reproduce?
questions.answer: Bacteria reproduce by binary fission. In this process, one cell divides into two identical cells.

questions.question: What are protozoa?
questions.answer: Protozoa are unicellular eukaryotic organisms. They usually live in water and some are disease causing.

questions.question: What are algae?
questions.answer: Algae are photosynthetic organisms found mostly in water. They can be unicellular or multicellular.

questions.question: What are fungi?
questions.answer: Fungi are non-green organisms that feed on dead or living matter. They reproduce by spores.

questions.question: Why are fungi called decomposers?
questions.answer: Fungi break down dead plants and animals into simpler substances. This helps recycle nutrients in nature.

questions.question: What is yeast?
questions.answer: Yeast is a unicellular fungus used in baking and fermentation. It reproduces by budding.

questions.question: What are viruses?
questions.answer: Viruses are non-living outside host cells but show life activities inside living cells. They need a host to reproduce.

questions.question: Why are viruses called obligate parasites?
questions.answer: Viruses can survive and reproduce only inside living host cells. Outside the host, they are inactive.

questions.question: What diseases are caused by viruses?
questions.answer: Viruses cause diseases like polio, AIDS, influenza and COVID-19. These diseases spread rapidly.

questions.question: What is bacteriophage?
questions.answer: Bacteriophage is a virus that infects and destroys bacteria. It is used in medical research.

questions.question: What is amoeba?
questions.answer: Amoeba is a unicellular protozoan that moves using pseudopodia. It lives in pond water.

questions.question: How does amoeba move?
questions.answer: Amoeba moves using pseudopodia which are temporary projections of cytoplasm. They also help in feeding.

questions.question: What is Paramecium?
questions.answer: Paramecium is a unicellular protozoan that moves with the help of cilia. It lives in water.

questions.question: What is Euglena?
questions.answer: Euglena is a unicellular organism showing both plant and animal characters. It can perform photosynthesis.

questions.question: What is Chlorella?
questions.answer: Chlorella is a unicellular green alga. It is rich in proteins and used as food supplement.

questions.question: What is Plasmodium?
questions.answer: Plasmodium is a protozoan parasite that causes malaria. It is transmitted by female Anopheles mosquito.

questions.question: What is Entamoeba histolytica?
questions.answer: It is a parasitic protozoan that causes amoebiasis. It infects the human intestine.

questions.question: What are saprotrophs?
questions.answer: Saprotrophs obtain food from dead and decaying matter. Many fungi are saprotrophs.

questions.question: What are parasites?
questions.answer: Parasites live on or inside other organisms and take food from them. They harm the host.

questions.question: What are symbionts?
questions.answer: Symbionts are organisms that live together and benefit each other. Lichen is an example.

questions.question: What is lichen?
questions.answer: Lichen is a symbiotic association between algae and fungi. Both benefit from each other.

questions.question: How are microorganisms useful to humans?
questions.answer: They help in food production, medicine, decomposition and nitrogen fixation. Some are used in industries.

questions.question: How are microorganisms harmful?
questions.answer: They cause diseases in humans, animals and plants. They can spoil food and damage crops.

questions.question: What is vaccination?
questions.answer: Vaccination is the method of introducing weakened germs to develop immunity against diseases.

questions.question: What are antibiotics?
questions.answer: Antibiotics are medicines used to kill or stop growth of bacteria. They are not effective against viruses.

questions.question: Why should antibiotics be used carefully?
questions.answer: Overuse can lead to antibiotic resistance. This makes treatment of diseases difficult.

questions.question: What is pasteurization?
questions.answer: Pasteurization is heating milk to kill harmful microorganisms. It increases shelf life of milk.

questions.question: How do microorganisms help in agriculture?
questions.answer: They increase soil fertility by nitrogen fixation and decomposition. Some are used as biofertilizers.

questions.question: What are nitrogen fixing bacteria?
questions.answer: They convert atmospheric nitrogen into usable form for plants. Example is Rhizobium.

questions.question: What is fermentation?
questions.answer: Fermentation is conversion of sugar into alcohol or acids by microorganisms like yeast.

questions.question: What is curd formation?
questions.answer: Bacteria convert lactose in milk into lactic acid, forming curd. Lactobacillus helps in this process.

questions.question: How do microorganisms spoil food?
questions.answer: They grow on food and produce harmful substances. This causes bad smell, taste and diseases.

questions.question: What is food preservation?
questions.answer: Food preservation prevents growth of microorganisms to avoid spoilage. It increases shelf life.

questions.question: Name some food preservation methods.
questions.answer: Drying, salting, refrigeration and preservatives are common food preservation methods.

questions.question: What are preservatives?
questions.answer: Preservatives are chemicals added to food to prevent microbial growth and spoilage.

questions.question: Why refrigeration prevents spoilage?
questions.answer: Low temperature slows down growth of microorganisms, thus preventing food spoilage.

questions.question: What are spores?
questions.answer: Spores are reproductive structures in fungi that help in survival under unfavorable conditions.

questions.question: What is colony formation in bacteria?
questions.answer: Bacteria multiply rapidly and form visible groups called colonies under suitable conditions.

questions.question: Why are microorganisms important in ecosystem?
questions.answer: They decompose waste and recycle nutrients, maintaining ecological balance.

questions.question: How do microbes help in sewage treatment?
questions.answer: They break down organic waste into harmless substances, purifying water.

questions.question: What is biofertilizer?
questions.answer: Biofertilizers contain living microorganisms that enrich soil nutrients and improve crop yield.

questions.question: Why are microorganisms studied in biology?
questions.answer: They play important roles in health, environment and industries. They help understand life processes.

questions.question: What is host?
questions.answer: Host is the organism that provides food and shelter to parasites or viruses.

questions.question: How does malaria spread?
questions.answer: Malaria spreads through bite of infected female Anopheles mosquito carrying Plasmodium.

questions.question: How can microbial diseases be prevented?
questions.answer: Cleanliness, vaccination, safe drinking water and proper sanitation prevent diseases.

questions.question: What is immunity?
questions.answer: Immunity is the ability of body to resist infections and fight against pathogens.

questions.question: What are pathogens?
questions.answer: Pathogens are disease causing microorganisms. They infect humans, animals and plants.

questions.question: How do microorganisms enter human body?
questions.answer: They enter through air, water, food, wounds or insect bites and cause infection.

questions.question: What is contamination?
questions.answer: Contamination means presence of harmful microorganisms in food or water.

questions.question: What is culture of bacteria?
questions.answer: It is the process of growing bacteria in laboratory using nutrient media.

questions.question: Why are microscopes needed to study microbes?
questions.answer: Microbes are too small to be seen with naked eyes, so microscopes help observe them.

questions.question: What is classification based on?
questions.answer: It is based on structure, mode of nutrition, reproduction and genetic similarities.

questions.question: What is kingdom Monera?
questions.answer: It includes prokaryotic organisms like bacteria and blue-green algae.

questions.question: What is kingdom Protista?
questions.answer: It includes unicellular eukaryotic organisms like amoeba and paramecium.

questions.question: What is kingdom Fungi?
questions.answer: It includes organisms that are non-photosynthetic and obtain food by absorption.

questions.question: What is kingdom Plantae?
questions.answer: It includes multicellular green plants that perform photosynthesis.

questions.question: What is kingdom Animalia?
questions.answer: It includes multicellular animals that depend on others for food.

questions.question: How are microbes used in medicine?
questions.answer: They are used to produce antibiotics, vaccines and vitamins.

questions.question: What is antibiotic resistance?
questions.answer: It is when bacteria become resistant to antibiotics making treatment ineffective.

questions.question: How do microbes help in recycling matter?
questions.answer: They decompose dead organisms and release nutrients back into environment.

questions.question: What is microbiology?
questions.answer: Microbiology is the study of microorganisms and their effects.

questions.question: Why are microorganisms called invisible helpers?
questions.answer: They perform many useful functions that we cannot see but are essential.

questions.question: What is hygienic food?
questions.answer: Food that is free from harmful microorganisms and safe to eat is hygienic food.

questions.question: What is composting?
questions.answer: It is conversion of organic waste into manure by microorganisms.

questions.question: How do microbes help in industry?
questions.answer: They are used in production of alcohol, cheese, curd and medicines.

questions.question: Why are viruses difficult to kill?
questions.answer: They live inside host cells and do not respond to antibiotics.

questions.question: How does vaccination protect us?
questions.answer: It develops antibodies that fight disease causing microorganisms.

questions.question: What is epidemic?
questions.answer: When a disease spreads rapidly in a large area, it is called epidemic.

questions.question: What is pandemic?
questions.answer: A disease that spreads worldwide affecting many countries is called pandemic.

questions.question: How can we prevent microbial growth in food?
questions.answer: By refrigeration, drying, preservatives and proper cooking.

questions.question: Why should hands be washed before eating?
questions.answer: To remove harmful microbes and prevent diseases.

questions.question: What is sterile condition?
questions.answer: It is a condition free from microorganisms.

questions.question: What are useful microbes called?
questions.answer: They are called beneficial microorganisms.

questions.question: Why are microbes important in soil?
questions.answer: They improve soil fertility and decompose organic matter.

questions.question: What is culture medium?
questions.answer: It is a nutrient material used to grow microbes in laboratories.

questions.question: What is cell wall in fungi made of?
questions.answer: Fungal cell wall is made of chitin.

questions.question: What is host cell?
questions.answer: Cell that provides environment for virus reproduction is host cell.

questions.question: Why are microbes studied in medicine?
questions.answer: To understand diseases and develop treatments.

questions.question: What is microbial culture used for?
questions.answer: To identify microbes and study their behavior.

questions.question: What is pathogen transmission?
questions.answer: It is spread of disease from one host to another.

questions.question: What is incubation period?
questions.answer: Time between infection and appearance of symptoms is incubation period.

questions.question: Why are microbes essential for life?
questions.answer: They recycle nutrients and support food chains.

questions.question: What is microbial ecology?
questions.answer: It is study of interactions of microbes with environment.

questions.question: How do microbes help in biotechnology?
questions.answer: They are used to produce enzymes and medicines.

questions.question: Why are microbes called double-edged sword?
questions.answer: They are both useful and harmful to humans.

questions.question: What is antiseptic?
questions.answer: It is chemical that kills microbes on living tissues.

questions.question: What is disinfectant?
questions.answer: Chemical used to kill microbes on non-living surfaces.

questions.question: What is immunity booster?
questions.answer: Substance that improves body resistance against diseases.

questions.question: Why are viruses not included in five kingdom system?
questions.answer: They are not truly living organisms outside host.

questions.question: What is microbial diversity?
questions.answer: Variety of microorganisms found in different environments.

questions.question: Why is study of microbes important?
questions.answer: They affect health, agriculture, industry and environment.

questions.question: Give conclusion of living world and microbes chapter.
questions.answer: Microorganisms play vital roles in life and environment. Proper knowledge helps in using them beneficially and preventing diseases.
